dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, big news out this week, uh, regarding the Oxford-Moderna vaccine trials, specifically for older adults.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, big news out this week, uh, regarding the Oxford-Moderna vaccine trials, specifically for older adults.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Covid-19 vaccine being developed by the University of Oxford and AstraZeneca is safe and able to generate a robust immune response in older adults, according to early findings from Phase 2 clinical trials published in medical journal The Lancet Wednesday, findings researchers describe as encouraging given the high risk older adults have of developing serious Covid-19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, A, really interesting stuff coming out of The New England Journal of Medicine. So, essentially, they're saying the vaccine, it's, um, it's safe, and it *does* generate an immune response in older folks, which is, you know, good.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Covid-19 vaccine being developed by the University of Oxford and AstraZeneca is safe and able to generate a robust immune response in older adults, according to early findings from Phase 2 clinical trials published in medical journal The Lancet Wednesday...

dialogue_turns.text: Right, good. But then, um, the researchers also called some of the findings "discouraging." Like, what's going on there? It feels a bit contradictory, doesn't it?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The results from a Phase 2 clinical trial studying the response of the vaccine in 560 adults, including 240 over the age of 70 found a similar immune response in all ages studied.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, okay. So, not as robust as they maybe hoped for?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, okay. So, not as robust as they maybe hoped for?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And, um, Professor Pollard, the lead author, actually mentioned that usually, older adults, their immune systems actually respond *better* to vaccines, which makes these weaker results, you know, a bit concerning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And, um, Professor Pollard, the lead author, actually mentioned that usually, older adults, their immune systems actually respond better to vaccines, which makes these weaker results, you know, a bit concerning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Typically, older adults respond less well to vaccines as the immune system gradually deteriorates with age, says lead author Professor Andrew Pollard.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, um, the side effects, too, right? Pain, headache, fatigue... apparently, they were actually *more* common and, like, quite severe in older adults.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, um, the side effects, too, right? Pain, headache, fatigue... apparently, they were actually more common and, like, quite severe in older adults.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The adverse reactions to the vaccine which researchers described as mild, including injection site pain, headache and fatigue were also less common in older adults.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, that's what Dr. John Smith, a co-author, noted. Which again, is, uh, not ideal. But here's the thing that really stuck out to me: Smith said these 'weak immune responses' in older people were actually *encouraging*.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr Maheshi Ramasamy, a co-author of the study, said the robust immune responses seen in older people are encouraging.
